| 1178   | enhance the rate limit to support sliding window and limit   based on IP and client_id                  | open   |              |           | stevehu           | GavinChenYan      | GavinChenYan      | 2022-03-20T23:46:43Z | 2022-03-25T16:00:32Z |                      | The current rate limit is based on   the concurrent model. I can set how many concurrent requests can pass   through. This works if the backend service is slow. For faster backend   service or business handler in the same instance, even we set with only one   concurrent request, the server can still handle thousands of requests per   second. And this behaviour can not pass the penetration test from one of our   customers to use the light-gateway.             Here are the features we want to add to the new implementation.             1. allow set up rate limiting based on the time slot. For example, 10   requests per minute or 100 requests per hour, etc.      2. guarantee requests to be processed as fast as possible. (Leaky bucket is   not meeting this requirement)      3. need to avoid spike of requests (Fixed window is not meeting this   requirement)      4. can set rate limit at server level or IP level or client_id (from JWT)   level. For example, each client can send 10 requests per minute.      5. can set the rate limit differently based on client_id to give priority   client more throughput than others. For example, client A can send 100   requests per minute and all others can send only 10 requests per minute.               Given the above requirement, I think we should use the sliding window.           https://medium.com/@NlognTeam/design-a-scalable-rate-limiting-algorithm-system-design-nlogn-895abba44b77            When IP is used, we can put the rate limit handler at the beginning of the   chain. When client_id is use, we must put the rate limit handler after the   JwtVerifier before the validation.             #############            Had a discussion with the users and we need to add the following features.               1. If the server is selected as a key, we cannot allow the user to select   quota which is the second part of the rate limit. Otherwise, the server will   not respond to any client after the quota is exceeded.       2. We need to create a key resolver as they are many ways to identify the   client or address. For example, the client_id might be in the JWT token, in   the header if JWT is not supported, in the query parameter, etc.      3. When the address is used as the key, we also need to check the original   IP in the header if the request is from a reverse proxy like Akamai.       4. We need to add the rate limit response header based on this doc.   https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-httpapi-ratelimit-headers | 1169   | undertow's ExchangeCompletionListener                                                                   | open   |              |           | yibogithub        |                   |                   | 2022-03-18T15:13:30Z | 2022-03-18T15:29:13Z |                      | Hi team,            We use 1.6.x running into a situation where some of our existing code   relies on an ExchangeCompletionListener being executed on the handler chain   thread. We use a slf4j's MDC in a callback listener and expect it to be a   continuation of that on the handler chain thread producing logs with the   right MDC values.            While it does not look right to me, it actually worked. I expect the   listener being executed on its own thread or a shared thread managed by   undertow; but a completion listener of ours is indeed executed on the same   thread thus inheriting the right MDC values.            I am not super sure how this could have happened. At the moment It seems to   me an explicit call to exchange.endExchange() might have been the   cause.            This is not an light4j issue but I tend to think one should not expect an   ExchangeCompletionListener being executed on the handler chain thread.            Thanks! When this option is      # selected, you can not use the bodyAttributesToIgnore list.      bodyAttributesToEncode: ${sanitizer.bodyAttributesToEncode:}      # pick up a list of keys to ignore the values encoding to skip some of the   values so that these      # values won't be encoded. Please refer to site      #   https://github.com/OWASP/owasp-java-encoder/blob/main/core/src/main/java/org/owasp/encoder/Encoders.java      headerEncoder: ${sanitizer.headerEncoder:javascript-attribute}      # pick up a list of keys to encode the values to limit the scope to only   selected keys. You can      # choose this option if you want to only encode certain fields in the body.   When this option is      # selected, you can not use the headerAttributesToIgnore list.      headerAttributesToEncode: ${sanitizer.headerAttributesToEncode:}      # pick up a list of keys to ignore the values encoding to skip some of the   values so that these      # values won't be encoded. You can choose this option if you want to encode   everything except      # several values with a list of the keys. When this option is selected, you   can not use the      # headerAttributesToEncode list.      headerAttributesToIgnore: ${sanitizer.headerAttributesToIgnore:}            ``` | 1118   | allow router to support serviceId from query parameters along   with headers                            | closed |              |           | stevehu           |                   |                   | 2022-02-23T17:57:47Z | 2022-02-23T18:57:56Z | 2022-02-23T18:01:29Z | When using the light-router as a   centralized gateway, some users want to put the serviceId in the query   parameters instead of headers as some legacy client doesn't have a way to   manipulate headers. To support those clients, we are going to do the following.               1. If serviceIdQueryParameter flag in router.yml is true, overwrite the   serviceId from the headers and use it from the query parameter if there is   one.      2. If it is there, we will use it and remove it from the query parameters to   prevent downstream API receives this query parameter. While the   properties still exist.      They can no longer be used to configure the driver logging. This      would allow a malicious class to be instantiated that could execute   arbitrary code from the JVM. | 1083   | Bump h2 from 1.4.196 to 2.0.206                                                                         | closed | dependencies |           | dependabot[bot]   |                   |                   | 2022-01-06T23:59:39Z | 2022-01-07T16:13:59Z | 2022-01-07T16:13:56Z | Bumps   [h2](https://github.com/h2database/h2database) from 1.4.196 to 2.0.206.      <details>      <summary>Release notes</summary>      <p><em>Sourced from <a   href="https://github.com/h2database/h2database/releases">h2's   releases</a>.</em></p>      <blockquote>      <h2>Version 2.0.206</h2>      <p>Critical <a   href="https://github.com/h2database/h2database/security/advisories/GHSA-h376-j262-vhq6">security   issue</a> with H2 console is fixed.</p>      <p>Also important changes included:</p>      <!-- raw HTML omitted -->      <h2>Version 2.0.204</h2>      <p>Multilple regression fixes discovered after 2.0.202   release,</p>      <p>There are no persistence changes between 2.0.202 and 2.0.204, so   jar file swap is enough, if database had been upgraded to 2.0.202 already,   otherwise please read the message below:</p>      <p>Between version 1.4.200 and version 2.0.202 there have been   considerable changes, such that a simple update is      not possible.      The official way to upgrade is to do a BACKUP of your existing database   <strong>USING YOUR CURRENT VERSION OF H2.</strong>      Then create a fresh database <strong>USING THE NEW VERSION OF   H2</strong>, then perform a SCRIPT to load your data.</p>      <h2>Version 2.0.202</h2>      <p>Besides many dozens of fixed bugs, performance improvements,      more adherence to a standard SQL syntax and type system, there   are</p>      <p>Some new features:</p>      <ul>      <li>Complete re-work of INFORMATION_SCHEMA to be more in-line with   the standard</li>      <li>Support for new types: ARRAY, ROW, JAVA_OBJECT</li>      <li>Numerous bit, string, array and system functions   implemented</li>      <li>Standard-based access to generated keys</li>      <li>JDBC 4.2 compliance</li>      <li>Support for JDK 7 is dropped</li>      <li>PageStore is discontinued</li>      </ul>      <p>MVStore changes:</p>      <ul>      <li>Descending MVMap and TransactionMap cursor</li>      <li>Disk space reclamation algorithm improvements</li>      </ul>      <p>Between version 1.4.200 and version 2.0.202 there have been considerable   changes, such that a simple update is      not possible.      The official way to upgrade is to do a BACKUP of your existing database   <strong>USING YOUR CURRENT VERSION OF H2.</strong>      Then create a fresh database <strong>USING THE NEW VERSION OF   H2</strong>, then perform a SCRIPT to load your data.</p>      <h2>Version 1.4.200</h2>      <p>Some new features:</p>      <ul>      <li>JSON data type; JSON_OBJECT, JSON_ARRAY, JSON_OBJECTAGG, and   JSON_ARRAYAGG functions; JSON predicate</li>      <li>TIME WITH TIME ZONE data type</li>      <li>BITNOT, LSHIFT, and RSHIFT functions</li>      </ul>      <!-- raw HTML omitted -->      </blockquote>      <p>... | 1029   | Transform List to Set for Better Performance                                                            | open   |              |           | FastAtlas         |                   |                   | 2021-09-03T16:30:42Z | 2021-09-03T16:30:42Z |                      | Hi,      We find that the List allocated at line 85 in the function   `isExclusionConfigFile` is only used to check whether an element is stored in   the container. The method `contains` of a list runs in linear time   complexity. We notice that the `exclusionFileList` is maintained in the   HashMap `exclusionMap`, which maps a string object to an object.            To achieve the same functionality, maybe a `HashSet` can provide a more   efficient implementation. We can just construct a HashSet and maintain it in   the HashMap `exclusionMap`. When we invoke the function   `isExclusionConfigFile`, we only need to take amortized O(1) time to maintain   the map and invoke the `contains` method of `HashSet`.            We discovered this inefficient usage of containers by our tool Ditto. The   patch is submitted in #1028 . Could you please check and accept it? We have   tested the patch on our PC. The patched program works well. Of course, it   would be better to change `EXCLUSION_CONFIG_FILE_LIST` to `EXCLUSION_CONFIG_FILE_Set`.   Anyway, the name does not affect the performance anymore.            Bests            Ditto | 1028   | Inefficient Usages of Java Collections                                                                  | open   |              |           | FastAtlas         |                   |                   | 2021-09-03T16:29:59Z | 2021-09-14T07:50:28Z |                      | Hi,      We find that the List allocated at line 85 in the function   `isExclusionConfigFile` is only used to check whether an element is stored in   the container. The method `contains` of a list runs in linear time   complexity. We notice that the `exclusionFileList` is maintained in the   HashMap `exclusionMap`, which maps a string object to an object.            To achieve the same functionality, maybe a `HashSet` can provide a more   efficient implementation. We can just construct a HashSet and maintain it in   the HashMap `exclusionMap`. When we invoke the function   `isExclusionConfigFile`, we only need to take amortized O(1) time to maintain   the map and invoke the `contains` method of `HashSet`.            We discovered this inefficient usage of containers by our tool Ditto. The   patch is submitted. Could you please check and accept it? We have tested the   patch on our PC. The patched program works well. Of course, it would be   better to change `EXCLUSION_CONFIG_FILE_LIST` to `EXCLUSION_CONFIG_FILE_Set`.   Anyway, the name does not affect the performance anymore.            Bests            Ditto
